            </choice> of the middle ages <add hand="ms" place="inline">]</add> desires</l>

            <choice>
              <sic>weath</sic>
              <corr>wealth</corr>
            </choice>, now history, now</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">instruction, now poetry itself, and now what will make them</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">forget the that life is ugly, or drab. As the book</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">becomes more covered over <add hand="ms" place="above">with these influences</add>, the thing that the writer ser</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">set out to say becomes increasingly 
            <choice>
              <sic>encu bered</sic>
              <corr>encumbered</corr>
            </choice>. It is only</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to be discovered in a flash of 
            <choice>
              <sic>recgnition</sic>
              <corr>recognition</corr>
            </choice>; Some say they</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">feel it--<del hand="ms">the original, the vital</del>--when their beards bristle.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Others that a 
            <choice>
              <sic>trhill</sic>
              <corr>thrill</corr>
            </choice> runs down the nerves of the thigh.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">To disengage the song from its encumbrances becomes as time</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">goes on, a task for the critic-- that specially equipped</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">official who was 
            <choice>
              <sic>carcely</sic>
              <corr>scarcely</corr>
            </choice> in 
            <choice>
              <sic>existnce</sic>
              <corr>existence</corr>
            </choice> when <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs> emerged</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with his <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faer" key="Faerie Queene, The">Faery Queen</rs> from the depths of silence.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add hand="ms" place="inline">[</add>He had chosen his medium<add hand="ms" place="inline">:</add> <add hand="ms" place="above">&</add> The great English art</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was to be, not music, not painting, but the art of words.<add hand="ms" place="inline">]</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We call Spenser an artist, more so than the 
            <choice>
              <sic>misntels</sic>
              <corr>minstrels</corr>
            </choice> and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the song writers, because he was aware of his 
            <choice>
              <sic>medoum</sic>
              <corr>medium</corr>
            </choice>.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>H ewas</sic>
              <corr>He was</corr>
            </choice> conscious of the possibilities and of the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>limtations</sic>
              <corr>limitations</corr>
            </choice> of the English 
            <choice>
              <sic>lang age</sic>
              <corr>language</corr>
            </choice>. <quote>For why, a Gods name,</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">may not we, as else the Greekes, hav the kingdome of our owne</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">
              <choice>
                <sic>langauge</sic>
                <corr>language</corr>
              </choice>, and measure our accents by the sound ,</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">reserving the quantity to the verse?</quote> He applied 
              <choice>
                <sic>himslef</sic>
                <corr>himself</corr>
              </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to the art.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">And</del> <add hand="ms" place="inline">L</add>ike the 
            <choice>
              <sic>chornicler</sic>
              <corr>chronicler</corr>
            </choice>, the writer in order to use</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">his medium consciously, must be aware of the past. There must</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">be a golden age behind him<add hand="ms" place="inline">;</add> <del hand="ms">and</del> the present must be fallen,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">degenerate. But, while the modern writer with a long line</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">behind him, naturally <choice>
            <sic>at ackes</sic>
            <corr>attacks</corr>
